div.p: RABBLE a general term for a disorderly crowd, apparently connected with the verb “ to rabble, ” to talk or work in a confused manner, Du. rabbelen, Ger. dialect rabbeln, cf. Gr. ῥαβάσσϵιν , to howl. In iron and steel manufacture, a puddling-tool, for stirring the molten metal, is called a “ rabble. ” This is a different word, adapted from Fr. râble, for rouble, Med. Lat. rotabulum, Lat. rutabulum (ruere, to rake), a fire-shovel or oven rake.
